overview: VS Code 1.106 (October 2025) centers on an 'Agent HQ' experience for managing sessions, plus security/trust improvements and editor UX upgrades. It also continues the open-source AI editor effort by open-sourcing inline suggestions and consolidating Copilot extension functionality.

detailed_explanation.title: Agent HQ: sessions and planning
bullets: Agent Sessions view is enabled by default and can be configured with `setting(chat.agentSessionsViewLocation)`.
Supports a consolidated single view across providers via the `single-view` option on `setting(chat.agentSessionsViewLocation)`.
Adds search in the sessions list (`kb(list.find)`) to find sessions.
Introduces a Plan agent that asks clarifying questions and generates a plan that you approve before implementation.
Plan output can be implemented either locally or via cloud agents.

detailed_explanation.title: Cloud and CLI agent integrations
bullets: Migrates Copilot coding agent integration into the Copilot Chat extension for a more native cloud agent experience.
Improves deep-linking between VS Code and GitHub Mission Control for cloud agent sessions.
Adds initial integration with Copilot CLI, including creating/resuming sessions in chat editors or the integrated terminal.
Adds delegation UX for choosing among available agents, including delegating from the CLI via `/delegate`.

detailed_explanation.title: Custom agents and agent file authoring
bullets: Renames chat modes to custom agents and moves definitions to `.github/agents`.
Adds a `target` frontmatter property for describing how an agent should run across environments (vscode vs github-copilot).
Adds new metadata such as `name`, `argument-hint`, and `handoffs` for guided transitions.
Agent file editor provides validation, completions, hovers, and code actions.

detailed_explanation.title: Code editing and inline suggestions
bullets: Allows selecting and copying deleted lines in the diff editor (inline diff view).
Open-sources inline suggestions by merging into the `vscode-copilot-chat` repository.
Moves toward consolidating Copilot and Copilot Chat extensions (transparent by default; can revert via `setting(chat.extensionUnification.enabled)`).
Adds the ability to snooze inline suggestions from the gutter.
Improves Go to Line with character-offset navigation using `::`, including negative offsets from file end.

detailed_explanation.title: Editor experience and platform/enterprise features
bullets: Refreshes codicon iconography.
Adds Linux policy support using JSON files for administrator-managed settings.
Adds navigation across files in the multi-file diff editor.
Adds a copy button to diagnostic hover text.
Command Palette filtering becomes accent-insensitive using Unicode normalization.
Introduces the concept of advanced settings (hidden by default, visible via Advanced filter or `@tag:advanced`).

key_changes: Agent Sessions view enabled by default; supports consolidated view and search.
Plan agent for clarifying questions and pre-implementation planning.
Cloud agent integration moved into Copilot Chat extension; improved Mission Control deep links.
Initial Copilot CLI integration with chat editor/terminal experiences.
Chat modes renamed to custom agents; definitions in `.github/agents` with richer metadata (`target`, `handoffs`, etc.).
Deleted code selectable in diff editor.
Inline suggestions open-sourced; extension unification path via `setting(chat.extensionUnification.enabled)`.
Go to Line supports character offsets via `::` syntax.
impact: Anyone delegating work to agents: gets a central sessions hub and a clearer planâ†’implement workflow.
Extension authors and teams customizing agent behavior: need to adopt the new custom agent file conventions and metadata.
Developers reviewing diffs: can copy deleted lines and navigate multi-file diffs more efficiently.
Enterprise/Linux administrators: can enforce policies using JSON on Linux.
caveats: Some parts of the consolidated Agent Sessions view are noted as not yet having full functionality.
The inline suggestions consolidation/unification can be reverted via `setting(chat.extensionUnification.enabled)` if issues occur.
The timeline for deprecating the GitHub Copilot extension is mentioned as early 2026; exact dates and migration steps beyond settings are not stated in the article.
insights: The release frames AI work as session-oriented and multi-provider (Copilot, CLI agents, Codex), pushing toward a unified operational view.
Open-sourcing inline suggestions signals an intentional shift toward transparency and a single, cohesive AI extension surface.
The addition of agent metadata and editor validation suggests custom agents are moving from niche customization to a first-class workflow artifact.
